Award.AwardTitle: EDU: Collaborative: Cybersecurity for Middle School students at Museums: An Informal Learning Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will focus on the topic of Cybersecurity for Middle School Students at Museums in a joint effort between the University at Buffalo (UB) and the Tech Museum of Innovation (The Tech), San Jose. The project will span multiple disciplines ranging from computer science and information systems to forensics and law. The participants shall pay particular attention to concepts and conceptual understanding of cybersecurity. The project will involve the design, development, assessment and refinement of interactive and hands-on experiences in a museum setting, with follow-up workshops targeting middle school students. Given the wide-spread use of the Internet, cybercrime is on the rise and cybersecurity is a much needed component in any STEM curriculum. Exposing students to learning situations through exhibits is a form of informal learning, and the follow-up workshops complement this type of learning with a less informal and more in-depth coverage of the material. The Tech's Smart Museum infrastructure will also support data analysis in order to evaluate the educational efficacy and engagement of the hands-on museum experiences and workshops.

The partnership between UB and The Tech will: (a) develop and assess interactive museum exhibits on cybersecurity, and (b) develop and deliver targeted workshops to middle school students. The main objective for the exhibits will be to increase awareness of cybersecurity among a school audience. The main objective for the workshop series will be to build conceptual understanding and subject interest among young students who may otherwise not be exposed to the content. In an effort to help break down the perceived barriers to entry often associated with STEM fields and careers, various object lessons, demonstrations, puzzles, and examples will be extensively utilized. A detailed assessment of student learning and engagement throughout the workshop sessions will be conducted. Also, students in the Information Assurance Scholarship Program and the CyberCorps Program at UB will be involved in various aspects of the proposed project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcomes of this project are: i) a workshop to scaffold middle-school students' experiences with the Cyber Detectives exhibit at The Tech Museum of Innovation in San Jose, CA in an effort to encourage interest and engagement in cyber careers and cybersecurity learning, ii)  an intervention model designed to increase teenagers' problem-solving and cybersecurity awareness in informal settings and its evaluation, and iii) a web-based platform wherein users could engage with a system that has activities associated with discrete learning goals pertaining to safe cyber behavior. Two workshops for teaching students about networking and packet delivery were developed. These workshops were delivered to a group of middle school students at the Tech Museum of Innovation prior to their interaction with a Net Builder kiosk at the museum and the effects of intervention were studied. The study showed that interventions targeted at cybersecurity engagement and awareness can be effective, and can also help reduce gender gaps. However, the results seemed to suggest that in order for interventions to positively affect the relative outcomes, intervention intensity and type matter. The web-based platform was build off content from the Tech Museum of Innovation's stand-alone exhibit on cybersecurity, Cyber Detectives. This prototype has the potential to offer benefits to both individual student users and teachers, and to society as a whole. For teachers, this prototype offers means to overcome technical and domain-specific knowledge barriers, and for students, it offers a cybersecurity education delivery method that is interactive, relevant, fun, measurable, and driven by standards. Beyond access to the web and the app, there is no specialized equipment or knowledge needed to use the prototype in a classroom setting. Of utmost importance, the student tracking and learning analytics, aligned with standards, provide teachers with an easy mechanism to assess student learning. By overcoming the need to develop cybersecurity curriculum, and offering the ability to evaluate students, this drop-in learning opportunity can provide a complete front-to-back solution for teachers.
